Forbes and Walker Tea Brokers
MOST COMPREHENSIVE WEBSITE ON TEA
www.forbestea.com
Page 2
Page 2
COMMENTS
Auction offerings totalled 6 M/Kgs. There was improved demand for most varieties of tea.
Ex-Estate teas totalling 0.8 M/Kgs was sold this week in an outcry Action commencing at 8.30 a.m. at the second floor auditorium of the Ceylon Chamber of Commerce.
Improved demand and a firm to dearer trend in prices for most teas on offer.
Best Western BOP's- A few select invoices were firm and Rs. 20-40 per kg dearer, whilst the others were mostly firm. Corresponding BOPF - Select invoices gained by Rs. 20-40 per kg and substantially more following special inquiry, whilst the others were firm to dearer to a lesser extent. In the Below Best category, a range of BOP invoices gained up to Rs. 50 per kg and more, whilst the others were irregular. Corresponding BOPF's a selection of improved teas gained by Rs. 50-100 per kg and more following special inquiry, whilst the others were irregular. BOP's at the lower end of the market were generally firm up to Rs. 50 per kg dearer, whilst the corresponding BOPF's were firm and Rs. 20-40 per kg dearer. Uda Pussellawa BOP's Rs. 20-40 per kg dearer, whilst the BOPF's were firm and tended dearer. Uva's - Seasonal teas continued to sell well with prices of BOP and BOPF ranging between Rs. 2500-3600 per kg and Rs. 2250-2550 per kg respectively. Other non-seasonal teas gained up to Rs. 100 per kg.
CTC's - BP1's hardly any offerings. PF1's sold around last.
Improved demand from the continent Japan and China for the better liquoring teas, whilst  shippers to the CIS and Middle East continued to be active on wider cross section of teas.
Low Growns totalled approximately 2.4 M/Kgs, with the Leafy, Semi-Leafy, Tippy and Premium categories experienced fair demand.
In the Leafy and Semi-Leafy catalogues, Well-made BOP1's were firm, whilst Below Best together with the bolder varieties were easier. Teas at the bottom maintained. Select Best and Best  OP1's were easier,  whilst the balance were irregular following quality.  Well-made OPA / OP's were firm, whilst the balance sold around last levels. Select Best and Best PEK's along with the mixed/open varieties appreciated, whilst the balance were fully firm. PEK1's, in general appreciated.
In the Tippy catalogue, Select Best FBOP's were firm to easier, whilst the Best together with Below Best were  firm. Balance were easier . However, selection of bolder varieties appreciated.  FF1's, in general were firm.
In the Premium catalogue, Very Tippy Teas were firm to easier, whilst the Best and Below Best sold at last levels. Balance were irregular following quality.
World Tea News
FORBES & WALKER TEA BROKERS (PVT) LTD SALE OF - 12TH/ 13TH AUGUST 2025
Forbes and Walker Tea Brokers
MOST COMPREHENSIVE WEBSITE ON TEA
www.forbestea.com
Page 3
Page 3
MARKET
HIGH GROWN TEAS
BOP
Best Western's - A few select invoices were firm and Rs. 20-40 per kg dearer, whilst the others were mostly firm. In the Below Best category, a range of invoices gained up to Rs. 50 per kg and more, whilst the others were irregular. Teas at the lower end of the market were generally firm up to Rs. 50 per kg dearer. Nuwara Eliya's were irregular. Uda Pussellawa's were firm Rs. 20-40 per kg dearer. Uva's - Seasonal teas continued to sell well with prices ranging from Rs. 2,500-3,600 per kg, whilst the other non-seasonal types with reasonable brightness appreciated by up to Rs. 100 per kg.
BOPF
Best Western's - Select invoices gained by Rs. 20-40 per kg and substantially more following special inquiry, whilst the others were firm to dearer to a lesser extent. In the Below Best category, a selection of improved teas gained by Rs. 50-100 per kg and more following special inquiry, whilst the others were irregular. Teas at the lower end were firm and Rs. 20-40 per kg dearer. Nuwara Eliya's were irregular. Uda Pussellawa's were firm and dearer. Uva's - Seasonal teas, a majority of the invoices sold between Rs. 2,200-2,550 per kg, whilst the other non-seasonal types gained up to Rs. 100 per kg.
OP/OPA
Well-made varieties were firm to easier by Rs. 20 per kg, whilst the others and poorer sorts were firm to dearer by Rs. 20 per kg.
PEKOE/PEKOE1
Flavoury PEK's were easier by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the Orthodox Leafy PEK's were dearer by Rs. 30-50 per kg and more at times. Best PEK1's were dearer by Rs. 40-60 per kg. Teas at the lower end were firm to easier by Rs. 20 per kg. Few Best Rotovane PEK's gained by Rs. 50 per kg, whilst the others sold at last levels. Below Best and poorer sorts were irregular but were dearer.
FBOP/FBOPF1
Flavoury FBOP/FBOPF1's were discounted and mostly unsold, whilst the poorer sorts were easier by Rs. 20-40 per kg. Better Orthodox FBOP/FBOPF1's appreciated by Rs. 40-60 per kg, whilst the others and teas at the lower end held firm.

FBOP/FBOPF1

OFF GRADES
FGS1/FGS
Teas in the Best category which commenced firm to dearer, gained by Rs. 40 per kg and more as the sale progressed. Improved Below Best varieties were firm, whilst the others declined Rs. 20- 40 per kg. Teas at the lower end of the market were firm to selectively dearer. Low Growns- Best varieties were firm. Below Best varieties were irregular, whilst the poorer sorts were lower. CTC- In general, were irregularly lower.
BROKENS
Reducer varieties together with the clean leaf sorts in the Best category were firm to selectively dearer, whilst the others were lower by Rs. 20- 40 per kg. Teas at the bottom end of the market declined by Rs. 30-40 per kg.
BOP1A
Main Grade reducer varieties in the Best category were selectively dearer, whilst the balance eased by Rs. 20-30 per kg. Below Best varieties commenced easier by Rs. 20-40 per kg and declined further as the sale progressed. Poorer sorts declined by Rs. 20-30 per kg, whilst select invoices maintained last weeks' closing levels.

DUSTS
DUST1
Select Best Dust1's were firm on last weeks price levels. Best varieties appreciated by Rs. 60-80 per kg. The cleaner Below Best varieties appreciated substantially by Rs. 80-100 per kg, whilst the others together with the poorer sorts were firm to dearer by Rs. 20-40 per kg. A few selected invoices on the Low Grown Best variety, were substantially dearer due to special inquiry, whilst the others were dearer by Rs. 40-60 per kg. The Below Best varieties were firm, whilst the poorer sorts were firm to easier by Rs. 20-40 per kg. High and Medium Grown CTC's together with the Low Grown CTC's were firm to dearer Rs. 20-40 per kg.
DUST
Clean leaf secondaries were dearer by Rs. 40 per kg, whilst the poorer sorts declined by Rs. 20 per kg. The Low Grown Best varieties together with the poorer sorts remained firm.

CROP AND WEATHER
For the period  05 - 12 August 2025
Western/Nuwara Eliya Regions
The Western Region reported rain throughout the week, whilst the Nuwara Eliya Region reported bright weather. The Department of Meteorology expects rain in the Western and Nuwara Eliya regions in the week ahead.
Uva/Uda Pussellawa Regions
Bright weather and occasional showers were reported in both regions throughout the week. According to the Department of Meteorology showers are expected in the Uva and Uda Pussellawa regions in the week ahead.
Low Growns
The Low Grown Region reported bright weather throughout the week. Rain is expected in the Low Grown Region in the week ahead according to the Department of Meteorology.
Crop Intake
The Nuwara Eliya, Uva and Uda Pussellawa regions maintained the crop intake, whilst the Western and Low Grown regions reported a decrease.

MOMBASA AUCTION
SALE OF - 11 AND12 AUGUST 2025 (SALE 32)
There was good general demand for the 151,700 packages (10,128,416.00 kilos) on offer with 30.84% remaining unsold.
MARKETS
Pakistan Packers were strong while Bazaar, Yemen, and other Middle Eastern countries maintained support. Kazakhstan and other CIS states lent more support with improved absorption from Afghanistan. Egyptian Packers were slightly more active with UK steady but quite selective. There was no participation from Russia while Sudan and South Sudan were quiet. Local Packers were not active. Somalia showed some support at the lower end of the market.
OFFERINGS
Leaf Grades                     -    84,180 packages (5,510,903.00 kilos) - 32.95% unsold.
Dust Grades                   -     50,200 packages (3,728,715.00 kilos) - 34.34% unsold.
Secondary Grades           -     7,320 packages (   888,798.00 kilos) - 10.39% unsold.
LEAF GRADES (M2 & M3)
BP1:
Best - More irregular enquiry ranging between USC16 dearer for some lines to mostly easier by up to USC60.
Brighter - Saw irregular interest and varied between USC26 dearer to easier by up to USC6.
Mediums - KTDA mediums saw more irregular demand and varied between steady to USC9 above last levels to easier by up to USC10 while plantation mediums were well competed for with some teas up to USC12 dearer.
Lower Medium - Appreciated by up to USC16 with select lines up to USC3 easier.
Plainer - Dearer by up to USC22 but some invoices were up to USC1 below previous rates.
PF1:
Best - Gained up to USC20 but select teas were USC5 below last rates.
Brighter - Advanced by up to USC26 but a few invoices lost up to USC13.
Mediums - KTDA mediums appreciated by up to USC21 with some lines discounted by up to USC6. Plantation mediums were irregular varying between dearer by up to USC5 to USC17 below previous levels.
Lower Medium - Irregular interest and varied between firm to USC26 dearer to easier by up to USC16.
Plainer - Steady to mostly dearer by up to USC13 but select lines shed up to USC3.

Lower Medium - Firm to USC6 above previous rates to easier by up to USC5.
Plainer -  Mostly dearer by up to USC15.

BANGLADESH AUCTION
SALE OF - 11 AUGUST 2025 (SALE 14)
CTC LEAF: 54,162 packages of tea on offer met with a fair demand which slackened as the sale progressed.
BROKENS: Large Brokens met with fair interest but prices were easier than last. Smaller Brokens were fairly well supported at around last levels with only a few lines tending dearer. Plain teas once again met with a discriminating market and there were many withdrawals. BLF teas continued to meet with quite a good demand but there were more withdrawals this week.
FANNINGS: Good liquoring Fannings were in fairly good demand but were easier towards the end. Medium and plain types continued to meet with a discriminating market and prices dropped further with more withdrawals. BLF teas continued to meet with quite a good demand but there were more withdrawals this week.
DUST: 13,541 packages of tea on offer met with a fair demand with more withdrawals than last. Good liquoring Dusts were sold at easier levels and had few withdrawals.. Mediums were also an easier market with Tk.5/- to Tk.8/- less than last. Plain and BLF Dusts were an easier market and saw fair withdrawals. Blenders lent strong support with fair interest from the Loose tea buyers.
COMMENTS: There was more tea on offer this week and initially there was fair competition for good liquoring types which were fairly firm but these eased further with the progress of sale. Blenders lent a good support but owing to less competition from the Loose tea buyers particularly from the latter half of the sale and rates declined steadily.
Dusts were again an easier market.
Our Catalogue: (Sale 14) Avg : Tk 247.12, Sold 70.58% , (Sale 13) Avg : Tk 249.74 , Sold 73.15%

GUWAHATI AUCTION
SALE OF - 05 AUGUST 2025 (SALE 32)
Final Market Report
Market: CTC
There was fair general demand. All categories tended easier. Brown/ Plainer category teas witnessed significant withdrawals.
Buying Pattern: CTC.
There was selective enquiry from Western India/ North India / HUL and other packeteers .Limited Export enquiry was seen on the larger brokens.
Market: DUST
There was fair demand at generally easier rates commensurate with quality and with some withdrawals.
Buying Pattern: DUST
There was fair support from HUL on the better liquoring sorts. Western India/ North India buyers, other packeteers operated.
